properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snow will begin this afternoon. Snowfall accumulations will reach 30 to 40 cm by Saturday afternoon. In addition, an Arctic front will push through Pine Pass tonight producing northeast winds of 30 to 40 km/h with gusts to 60. The winds and snow will reduce visibility in blowing snow. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-28T04:16:50-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-27T12:17:50-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3215266837.2020
Area: Highway 97 - Pine Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Southerly gusts near 100 kilometres per hour are expected this afternoon and this evening. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-28T05:18:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-27T13:19:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3685819072.2020
Area: Salluit
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and blowing snow is expected Friday night and Saturday. Maximum snowfall: 10 cm with locally higher amounts possible. Strongest winds: northerly near 80 km/h. Time span: Friday evening to Saturday evening. Remarks: Snow will begin Friday afternoon and taper off Saturday evening. Strong northerly winds will develop Friday night and will persist on Saturday. These winds will combine with fresh snow to cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-27T17:16:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-27T01:17:14-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0612035303.2020
Area: Nain and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Total snowfall: 20 to 30 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northerly 80 km/h. Locations: Makkovik to Hopedale and vicinity. Time span: Friday afternoon until Saturday evening. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, is expected to develop Friday afternoon and taper off Saturday evening. Strong northerly winds will develop Friday evening and persist through Saturday. Conditions will improve by Saturday evening. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-27T17:12:54-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-27T01:13:54-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2071634338.2020
Area: Postville - Makkovik, Hopedale and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 40 cm is expected. Locations: Upper Lake Melville, Eagle River, and Rigolet and vicinity. Time span: today until Saturday evening. Remarks: Northeasterly to northwesterly winds gusting to 60 or 70 km/h will combine with the fresh snowfall to give blowing snow at times tonight and Saturday, especially over exposed areas. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-28T05:47:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-27T13:48:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2905352298.2020
Area: Rigolet and vicinity, Upper Lake Melville, Eagle River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 40 cm. Freezing rain: 5 to 10 mm possible. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly up to 60 km/h. Les Suetes winds up to 90 km/h. Locations: eastern Nova Scotia, including Cape Breton. Time span: until Friday morning except into the afternoon for the Cape Breton Highlands. Remarks: Snow will transition to a mix of ice pellets or freezing rain overnight. Freezing rain is expected to change over or mix with rain mainly over eastern Cape Breton before switching back to flurries Friday afternoon. Over the Cape Breton Highlands, a switch over to snow and blowing snow with reduced visibility is expected on Friday. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-27T17:31:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-27T01:32:14-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2884988806.2020
Area: Guysborough County, Antigonish County, Richmond County, Inverness County - south of Mabou, Inverness County - Mabou and north, Victoria County, Sydney Metro and Cape Breton County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. The coldest wind chill values will be near minus 55. Very cold wind chills near minus 55 are occurring at Cambridge Bay this morning, but will moderate by this afternoon. Wind chill values near minus 55 are expected to return overnight into Saturday morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-28T06:14:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-27T14:15:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0882084682.2020
Area: Cambridge Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. Locations: Deer Lake, and Green Bay - White Bay. Time span: continuing until this afternoon. Additional snow and ice pellets amounts: up to 5 cm. Remarks: Snow or ice pellets will transition to rain this afternoon. The rain will be accompanied by mild temperatures, resulting in snow melt and pooling water. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A snowstorm is expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 25 cm. Maximum wind gusts: easterly near 80 km/h. Location: the eastern half of the Great Northern Peninsula. Time span: continuing until this evening. Remarks: Snow at times heavy and strong easterly winds will combine to reduce visibility in blowing snow today. Conditions will improve this evening as the snow transitions to rain. ### Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Total snowfall: an additional 15 to 20 cm in snow squalls. Maximum wind gusts: 60 km/h. Locations: western Cape Breton. Time span: this evening and overnight. Remarks: Flurries will become heavy at times this evening, with risk of snow squall activity. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-28T05:42:17-00:00

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A storm system approaching from the south has brought blizzard conditions to Resolute. These blizzard conditions will be accompanied with very strong easterly winds of 70 gusting 90 km/h. Conditions will improve near midnight tonight as the winds weaken. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A total of 15 to 20 centimetres of snow as well as blowing snow are expected over these regions. Snow at times heavy along with northeasterly winds of up to 90 kilometres per hour will affect the Lower North Shore today. Quickly accumulating snow and reduced visibilities could make travel difficult. A period of rain is also possible over Blanc-Sablon this evening. Conditions should improve early Saturday morning. ### Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Total rainfall: 25 mm. Locations: the southwest coast and east coast of Newfoundland. Time span: continuing until late this afternoon or early this evening. Remarks: Rain at times heavy will be accompanied by mild temperatures and strong easterly winds, resulting in significant snow melt. As a result, localized flooding is likely. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Brief, intense snowfall is expected to develop. Under the snow squall, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow. Visibility in snow and blowing snow could significantly be reduced late this afternoon and evening as an Arctic front blasts through the region. The sudden onset of snow with strong winds will likely create visibilities near zero in blowing snow for a brief period of time as the front passes. Visibilities will improve late this evening in the wake of the front. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-28T04:09:17-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-27T12:10:17-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2051834702.2020
Area: B.C. South Peace River, B.C. North Peace River
